answer_html: The last sum diverges because of the series p test with p=1.
answer_latex:
The last sum diverges because of the series \emph{p} test with
\emph{p=1}.
hints_html:
Use the series p test.

If you do not see a possibility to use the series p test, try to estimate the sum downstairs.
hints_latex:
If you do not see a possibility to use the series \emph{p} test, try to
estimate the sum downstairs.
hints_raw:
Use the series ''p'' test.
If you do not see a possibility to use the series ''p'' test, try to estimate the sum downstairs.
question: 1 (a)
sols_html:
The difference between the highest exponents is 1.1-0.1 = 1. By the series p test (with p = 1) this series diverges.

More precisely we can prove

\(\sum_{n=1}^\infty\frac{n^{0.1}}{n^{0.99} + n^{1.1}+1} > \sum_{n=1}^\infty \frac{n^{0.1}}{n^{1.1} + n^{1.1} + n^{1.1}} = \sum_{n=1}^\infty\frac{n^{0.1}}{3n^{1.1}} = \frac13\sum_{n=1}^\infty\frac1n=\infty\)

The last sum diverges because of the series p test with p=1.
sols_latex:
The difference between the highest exponents is 1.1-0.1 = 1. By the
series \emph{p} test (with \emph{p} = 1) this series \textbf{diverges}.

More precisely we can prove

$\sum_{n=1}^\infty\frac{n^{0.1}}{n^{0.99} + n^{1.1}+1} > \sum_{n=1}^\infty \frac{n^{0.1}}{n^{1.1} + n^{1.1} + n^{1.1}} = \sum_{n=1}^\infty\frac{n^{0.1}}{3n^{1.1}} = \frac13\sum_{n=1}^\infty\frac1n=\infty$

The last sum diverges because of the series \emph{p} test with
\emph{p=1}.
sols_raw:
The difference between the highest exponents is 1.1-0.1 = 1. By the series ''p'' test (with ''p'' = 1) this series '''diverges'''.



More precisely we can prove

<math> \sum_{n=1}^\infty\frac{n^{0.1}}{n^{0.99} + n^{1.1}+1} > \sum_{n=1}^\infty \frac{n^{0.1}}{n^{1.1} + n^{1.1} + n^{1.1}} = \sum_{n=1}^\infty\frac{n^{0.1}}{3n^{1.1}} = \frac13\sum_{n=1}^\infty\frac1n=\infty</math>


The last sum diverges because of the series ''p'' test with ''p=1''.
statement_html:
Answer the following multiple choice question. Check your answer very carefully. Your answer will be marked right or wrong (work will not be considered for this problem).

Does the sum

\[\begin{aligned} \sum_{n=1}^{\infty} \frac {n^{0.1}} {n^{0.99}+n^{1.1}+1}\end{aligned}\]

converge?

A. Converge.

B. Diverge.
statement_latex:
Answer the following multiple choice question. Check your answer very
carefully. Your answer will be marked right or wrong (work will not be
considered for this problem).

Does the sum

\begin{align*}
\sum_{n=1}^{\infty} \frac {n^{0.1}} {n^{0.99}+n^{1.1}+1}
\end{align*} converge?

A. Converge.

B. Diverge.
statement_raw:
Answer the following multiple choice question. Check your answer very carefully. Your answer will be marked right or wrong (work will not be considered for this problem).

Does the sum
:<math>
\sum_{n=1}^{\infty} \frac {n^{0.1}} {n^{0.99}+n^{1.1}+1}
</math>
converge?

A. Converge.

B. Diverge.
